ygData.subject: Networking networks
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi everyone, First of all, a note - until I ran into Neat recently, I hadn t experimented with neural networks for at least good 7 years, so I may be unaware

Subject: Networking networks
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=192109828; y=DzCYXfVhKUSsYxpB6SI0-LRydZjwcjcrxpMEO-xfWDYA1pVu4UHS-Pm0

Hi everyone,

First of all, a note - until I ran into Neat recently, I hadn=
't
experimented with neural networks for at least good 7 years, so I may
be=
 unaware of recent research. If I ask something that's terribly
obvious or =
that has been researched to death before, please let me
know.

Now, as to w=
hat's in my mind.

In my current tests with sharpNeat, two relatively obvio=
us things are
consistent:

1) The higher the number of inputs and outputs, =
the longer the time
that the network takes to converge to an optimum, by sh=
eer virtue of
the connecting and weighing possibilities to try

2) The more=
 complex the problem, the longer the time that the network
will take to con=
verge to an optimum, and the higher the likelihood a
neural net might not b=
e able to converge to an optimum value

The first problem can be solved in =
some cases by applying a smaller
network to the values separetly.  For inst=
ance, to find out which out
of 4 values is larger, we could

a) Create a ne=
twork with 4 inputs and 1 output, and attempt to train
it to recognize the =
larger of four values, and apply it once, or
b) Create a network with 2 inp=
uts and 1 output, train to to recognize
the larger of those two values, and=
 a apply it several times (once for
inputs 1-2, once for inputs 3-4, and on=
ce of the result of those)

While it might seem a trivial example, in my te=
sts case b converges
extremely quickly, whereas case b takes forever and ne=
ver quites get
it perfect.  Not only that, but a network that recognizes th=
e larger
between 2 values can be applied multiple times for N, so we don't
=
actually need the more complex version.

The second problem is a similar is=
sue: a complex problem could be
solved by breaking it down into smaller pie=
ces, training a network to
solve each of thesen, and then apply the pieces =
to the whole of the
problem.

If I can break down a problem into smaller pa=
rts, I'm more than happy
to.   So, suppose we train the several sub-network=
s, or even the
simpler case of just needing to apply a copy of the same net=
work
multiple times.  How do we glue them together?

One approach is, of co=
urse, doing it programatically.  Calling the
nets, evaluating the outputs, =
passing them to other nets, etc.   Sure,
that approach works well for the M=
aximizer which we wish to apply
multiple times, but could get complicated w=
hen you're growing a
network of dissimilar issues (like the second problem =
above).

Why not just connect these various neural networks as part of a hy=
brid
neural net?  And if we're doing that, why not apply the same NEAT
tech=
nique to the this hybrid neural network?   The algorithm would
probably hav=
e to be adapted so that it knows that the elements it
could randomly add or=
 remove are not only neurons but full networks,
with varying numbers of inp=
uts and outputs, which need to be
connected.

This may be more trouble than=
 it's worth, or it could already have
been done to death.   Any comments?

=


Ricardo J. M=E9ndez
